I had a dream! — my spirit was unbound</br>From the dark iron of its dungeon, clay,</br>And rode the steeds of Time; — my thoughts had sound,</br>And spoke without a word, — I went away</br>Among the buried ages, and did lay</br>The pulses of my heart beneath the touch</br>Of the rude minstrel Time, that he should play</br>Thereon, a melody which might seem such</br>As musing spirits love — mournful, but not too much!

I had a dream — and there mine eyes did see</br>The shadows of past deeds like present things—</br>The sepulchres of Greece and Hespery,</br>Aegyptus, and old landes, gave up their kings,</br>Their prophets, saints, and minstrels, whose lute-strings</br>Keep a long echo — yea, the dead, white bones,</br>Did stand up by the house whereto Death clings,</br>And dressed themselves in life, speaking of thrones,</br>And fame, and power, and beauty, in familiar tones!

I went back further still, for I beheld</br>What time the earth was one fair Paradise—</br>And over such bright meads the waters welled,</br>I wot the rainbow was content to rise</br>Upon the earth, when absent from the skies!</br>And there were tall trees that I never knew,</br>Whereon sate nameless birds in merry guise,</br>Folding their radiant wings, as the flowers do,</br>When summer nights send sleep down with the dew.

Anon there came a change — a terrible motion,</br>That made all living things grow pale and shake!</br>The dark Heavens bowed themselves unto the ocean,</br>Like a strong man in strife — Ocean did take</br>His flight across the mountains; and the lake</br>Was lashed into a sea where the winds ride—</br>Earth was no more, for in her merrymake</br>She had forgot her God — Sin claimed his bride,</br>And with his vampire breath sucked out her life's fair tide!

Life went back to her nostrils, and she raised</br>Her spirit from the waters once again—</br>The lovely sights, on which I erst had gazed,</br>Were not — though she was beautiful as when</br>The Grecian called her "Beauty" — sinful men</br>Walked i' the track of the waters, and felt bold—</br>Yea, they looked up to Heaven in calm disdain,</br>As if no eye had seen its vault unfold</br>Darkness, and fear, and death! — as if a tale were told!

And ages fled away within my dream;</br>And still Sin made the heart his dwelling-place,</br>Eclipsing Heaven from men; but it would seem</br>That two or three dared commune face to face,</br>And speak of the soul's life, of hope, and grace—</br>Anon there rose such sounds as angels breath—</br>For a God came to die, bringing down peace—</br>"Pan was not;" and the darkness that did wreathe</br>The earth, past from the soul — Life came by death!
